name: 圖書資訊學研究趨勢
description: This course will offer Ph.D. students with the understanding of the major problems, trends and developments in information science and librarianship. Further critical survey and discussion of current and classic research findings will be focused in the seminar.
goals: To understand and to familiarize the evolution structure, nature and environment of information science and librarianship
To be able to critically analyze works and trends in information science and librarianship
To facilitate and generalize a ground for choosing and/or evaluating their own future research

**COURSE DESCRIPTION**

This doctoral-level course is designed to offer students of advanced study the skill and knowledge to identify the trending concepts and technologies within and surrounding the field of Library and Information Science (LIS). In this seminar, doctoral students will explore the topics that are only leading towards the edge, but also moving, shaking, and redefining the foundation of LIS as an academic discipline, a practice profession, and an education ground. The topics will include, but not limited to the debate of open science, the dilemma of gender equity in information science, and the rise of interdisciplinarity and its impact on scholarly communication. The major activities will consist of reading and class participation, while independent research and study and group interaction will also add up to ensure students a positive transition and a successful learning experience. This course will be in the form of complete online teaching and learning, and will meet online twice a week.

**COURSE PHILOSOPHY**

The course is highly participatory, and, as such, students will engage in active learning through discussion, reading, guest talks, and term projects. Because of the emphasis on active learning, it is important that students attend each class meeting. If an absence is necessary, please ask a peer to share notes from the session and let the instructor know by e-mail that you will not attend.

My teaching belief is based upon the social constructivist notion of knowledge and learning, by which a learning community is created as a collaborative effort. Through active participation and interaction, members within this learning community help each other master the key concepts and ideas of the course.

**ASSIGNMENTS**

**Discussion Leader**

Each doctoral student must give one (or two) lecture(s) on his or her chosen theme(s), which should reflect the research direction of your interest. Discuss with course instructor for consent. In order to prepare the discussion of the trends, each discussion should:

1.     Read the assigned materials thoroughly

2.     Search for, locate and read other supporting materials

3.     Make a presentation on the chosen theme, in the presentation, please include

l   Introduce the concept (theme/trend)

l   Summarize and synthesize the reading materials

l   Identify the trends and directions (research trends and implications for practices)

l   Make a list of discussion questions (5 questions), and use these questions to facilitate meaningful conversation and engagement.

**Final Project (independent work)**

In this assignment, you will be submitting a poster/proposal/short paper to the following conferences (hopefully!).

Follow the submission guidelines for the template and format of your final work.

   American Library Association Annual Conference 2022, June 23-28, 2022 (Washington, D.C., USA)： [https://www.ala.org/conferencesevents/ala-upcoming-annual-conferences-liblearnx](https://www.ala.org/conferencesevents/ala-upcoming-annual-conferences-liblearnx)
